text:
- So we're all about
collecting data on people.

We're trying to get a good
health profile on people to see
what their health state looks like
so we can catch disease early.
And so we'll collect as much data

as possible about a person,
meaning sequence their genome,

we'll make thousands of
measurements out of their blood

and urine, wearable data,
all kinds of data to see
what their health state looks like.
Longitudinal sampling is another part,
tracking people over time,

so we can see shifts
from their health state
and that lets us catch disease early.

So you need to have
all the data brought in,

put into a very standardized
format, the ways
that you can set up computer algorithms
and these days, AI out based algorithms
to track people at a personal level.

The Stanford Data Ocean is
really helping us pull in the

data, standardize
the specific formats
that researchers can use it.

We're actually setting up
disease detection algorithms

and we need strong
capabilities to do this.
And that's where AWS kick in.

They really have, you know,
amazing cloud capabilities

and they helped us
build this system to be able

to pull in these data to
track people at scale.

And the goal is to do
it for the whole planet.

There's another unique aspect
to everything we're doing

with the Stanford Data
Ocean, which is education.
We not only built a platform

for storing this complex
research data for being able
to compute on it in the cloud and then try

and develop new algorithms,
new tracking systems,

but we're also trying to
educate the next generation
of researchers and scientists.

So I think we can better
manage our lives with data

and I think that's really
what it's all about.
And that's where I think the
partnership should be incredible.
